text: I have downloaded a few months worth of "BASIC" data from <http://historicdata.betfair.com|historicdata.betfair.com> - looking through the files I see loads of instances of "ltp" (last traded price) but absolutely no instances of "batb" (best available to back) or "batl" (best available to lay). The file specification document (here <https://historicdata.betfair.com/Betfair-Historical-Data-Feed-Specification.pdf>) says "The following data is returned by all data packages" so I was expecting some "batb"/"batl" info in my files. Is there something I missed?

text: using fixed kelly should remove some of the volatility but cashing out is only giving money away, I profit off this so I shouldn't really tell you not to but...

elements.text: using fixed kelly should remove some of the volatility but cashing out is only giving money away, I profit off this so I shouldn't really tell you not to but...

text: Under Kelly there might be circumstances where you close particular bets but it wouldn't be a blanket strategy. If you want a blanket strategy then you let them all run.

elements.text: Under Kelly there might be circumstances where you close particular bets but it wouldn't be a blanket strategy. If you want a blanket strategy then you let them all run.

text: For a whole heap of reasons you probably won't be able to use Kelly properly anyway though, so I wouldn't sweat it.

elements.text: For a whole heap of reasons you probably won't be able to use Kelly properly anyway though, so I wouldn't sweat it.

text: Just whatever you do don't close as a blanket strategy, that's a bad idea.

elements.text: Just whatever you do don't close as a blanket strategy, that's a bad idea.

text: If I'm betting with someone else's money and they don't mind the volatility then I'm sure you're right.

elements.text: If I'm betting with someone else's money and they don't mind the volatility then I'm sure you're right.

text: And it certainly makes my life simpler.

elements.text: And it certainly makes my life simpler.

text: Ask yourself how much you're willing to pay to reduce your volatility. There is a financial cost, which I suppose you might think is worth it - but you have to recognise that it's costing you money and probably quite a lot. In the moment that might be worth it to you or it might not - and how will you look back on throwing away a significant proportion of your returns? Could your closing bets even make your returns negative? All up to you to consider of course.

elements.text: Ask yourself how much you're willing to pay to reduce your volatility. There is a financial cost, which I suppose you might think is worth it - but you have to recognise that it's costing you money and probably quite a lot. In the moment that might be worth it to you or it might not - and how will you look back on throwing away a significant proportion of your returns? Could your closing bets even make your returns negative? All up to you to consider of course.

text: Thanks... I might consider cashing out some of my longer odds bets.

elements.text: Thanks... I might consider cashing out some of my longer odds bets.

text: So back to your original question - I'd say the basic data LTP is a totally reasonable way to estimate your ability to do that and analyse its effect on your returns and I wouldn't apply any transformation to is as you're potentially just introducing and unnecessary error.

elements.text: So back to your original question - I'd say the basic data LTP is a totally reasonable way to estimate your ability to do that and analyse its effect on your returns and I wouldn't apply any transformation to is as you're potentially just introducing and unnecessary error.

text: But if I use just ltp then I will get an over-optimistic outcome.

elements.text: But if I use just ltp then I will get an over-optimistic outcome.

text: That tends to be a feature of all historical analysis, my view is that it's better to acknowledge it and correct for it explicitly afterwards but there are different approaches.

elements.text: That tends to be a feature of all historical analysis, my view is that it's better to acknowledge it and correct for it explicitly afterwards but there are different approaches.

text: One of the problems with your * 1.02 for example is that it will effect different prices differently and that will skew your analysis, it also includes assumptions that we know aren't true - like the spread being the same across all prices. If you're not careful you can end up introducing all kinds of kinks in your analytical road. That's why I would prefer to keep your analysis as close to the source data as you can and then just discount it when you're all done.

elements.text: One of the problems with your * 1.02 for example is that it will effect different prices differently and that will skew your analysis, it also includes assumptions that we know aren't true - like the spread being the same across all prices. If you're not careful you can end up introducing all kinds of kinks in your analytical road. That's why I would prefer to keep your analysis as close to the source data as you can and then just discount it when you're all done.

text: But discount it - how?

elements.text: But discount it - how?

text: I presume you've got to make a guess at something somewhere.

elements.text: I presume you've got to make a guess at something somewhere.

text: Yes you're always going to have to guess a bit, but try to do it at the point where it's least damaging.

elements.text: Yes you're always going to have to guess a bit, but try to do it at the point where it's least damaging.

text: Think about what the purpose of your analysis is - it's to determine the best strategy and find the best bets right? It's not to tell you what your income will be next year (or it shouldn't be anyway). Viewed from that perspective your 'optimism discount' doesn't really matter.

elements.text: Think about what the purpose of your analysis is - it's to determine the best strategy and find the best bets right? It's not to tell you what your income will be next year (or it shouldn't be anyway). Viewed from that perspective your 'optimism discount' doesn't really matter.

text: If you're going to do that why not just take a stab at what you think your strategy will look like and try it with minimum stakes collecting the data as you go? That's far and away the best way to get a strategy going anyway. Real bets places are far more valuable than hypothetical historical ones.

text: My main challenge with my system is actually to get as much money on as early as possible when there are the biggest mistakes in the market. If I could bet at the bookies without being gubbed I'd bet the evening before. Sadly the exchanges are almost deserted at that time or offering silly odds. So now I'm thinking about 7? 8? 9?am ... looking for a sweet spot balancing market errors with liquidity.
